For desert we ordered two hot teas ($2.00) and chocolate cannoli - fantastic. The food was great, we loved it.

The place is very small and and it gets a little loud. When the 2 of us showed up (about 7:30 5/24) we were given table of 4 (the last one). In about 5 minutes later a table for 2( right in the middle of the restaurant) became available, and when  later more people were at the door the owner asked us to move, we politely refused. The drinks were on the table and I didn't feel like sitting in the middle of the traffic.  From that point on the owner kept throwing mean looks towards me. 

I don't think this is right to ask your patrons to move in order to accommodate other guests.

Anyway he did ruin the dining experience for me, but I repeat the food was awesome and I recommend.
author: J D.

description:
Thanks to all the great yelpers for helping us find this place.  We went into the city to see a play and decided to head to North Beach for some Italian for dinner.  Our friend had suggested another (more touristy) spot, but after checking the reviews, we ended up at Franchino's instead.  What a fantastic decision!

This is a family owned and run restaurant and it is fresh real Italian at its best.  The family run aspect made for a great relaxing environment.  The homemade fresh pasta was perfect.  The parpadelle and sausage special was delicious, as was the gnocchi.  We will definitely return here again.
author: Carol C.

description: This mom and pop shop serves up mouthwatering  authentic Italian food. What more could you ask for? I LOVE this place, the ambiance is homey and romantic. The food is divine. The owner will serenade you while your eating! I usually order the fettuccine with mushrooms and cream sauce with peas and pancetta. Who ever knew something so simple could so delicious! A tab for 2 would be just under $30 without drinks. MANGA! MANGA!
author: Sharon Y.

description: This place is so good I'm writing a review before I even leave the restaurant. Most restaurants on Colombus are terrible tourist traps so I was extremely skeptical when Mr Franchino invited me in. But the good yelp reviews convinced me to try it out and I'm so so glad I did. This was the best chicken piccata I've ever had in my life. I didn't even realize all the other chicken piccata I'd ever eaten had been overcooked until I had this perfect dish. The service was friendly, the decor was fine, my house chianti was nice, all the other factors were fine. But the food!!!! I will absolutely be back. This is the only real deal on the block.
author: Diana S.

description:
This place was really sub-par, especially in a neighborhood that is known for quality Italian food. Our bread was stale, the tomatoes in the caprese salad were mushy, the tortellini was too salty, the wine tasted like it had been open for a while, and the parmesan cheese looked like they just cracked open a can of Kraft.

The kicker was that i found a hair in my ravioli. The hair itself is forgivable - I understand that it happens occasionally - but I would at least expect the owner to be apologetic. Instead, he first denied that there was a hair, until I showed him up close, and then he insisted that his kitchen is clean anyway. He offered to replace the dish, but I wasn't really hungry. He charged me the full $14.95 for the ravioli anyway.

This seems like a sleazy tourist joint with sub-average food. You can do a lot better in North Beach.
author: Luke S.

description:
We've tried many places in Little Italy. Many are quite good but also a little touristy and flat (ie, for the masses) with their food.  Not Franchino!  When we arrived in the early evening on New Year's Eve 2011, we were told the Specials of the Day that the waitress' mom "had cooked up for the day." We knew we were in the right place with that! 
We had roasted veggies for appetizer, seafood pasta and grilled veal. And some decadent ice cream dessert. WOW all around. Everything was so simply cooked you could taste every morsel, so authentic we felt we were back in Italy (we recently visited Southern Italy), and so reasonably priced as compared to competitors on Columbus. 
Also, the atmosphere is intimate, familial, cozy. This is now our fave place in Little Italy!
author: Kandice M.

description:
Showed up 1.5 hours before my reservation for Valentine's dinner. The tiny restaurant was at the breaking point with several groups gathered by the door waiting for a table and guests eating shoulder to shoulder.

Despite the tight space, no one really lost their temper and I don't think anyone was too annoyed. Several people left the door open on the cold, wet, windy night and so some guests had to shout at them to shut it.

Eventually, we were seated an hour before our reservation thanks to the help of the very pleasant and friendly patriarch of the restaurant. He kept everyone entertained by singing, chatting, and making jokes. The rest of his family did a great job taking orders and clearing tables and bringing out food in the tight space. They were constantly smiling and made sure that we were happy.

I ordered the salmon risotto with aurora sauce and my girlfriend ordered the mushroom ravioli. We started with the calamari. We were certain it was grilled marinated squid, so we were unhappy to see a salad delivered. It was, however, a light and tasty way to start the dinner. The roasted bell peppers in the salad were fantastic and I only wish that they put more on the plate.

My risotto was fantastic. It was a heaping plate of deliciously creamy risotto with a fabulous pink sauce. The salmon looked a bit anemic and lacked any color at all, but it tasted great.

The mushroom ravioli was great, as well. I thought the flavor was a bit overpowering, but my girlfriend loved it. We were both thrilled to see a plate of more than your typical 5 or 6 ravioli. The plate was filled with puffy pasta pillows of tasty wild mushrooms in a cream sauce.

We both saved room for dessert and boxed up the leftover entrees. She ordered a tiramisu. It looked and tasted fantastic. It was a fluffy, substantive coffee cream on top of soaked lady fingers. It was a far cry from your average tiramisu bars and it was the better for it.

My night was nearly ruined when I ordered a zabaglione and was told by the matriarch that the one man who knew how to make the zabaglione was out of the kitchen tonight.

I have to admit. I put my hands to my face and shouted "oh NO!" at the news. It was one reason I picked the restaurant and it's one of the few restaurants in my life that serves my favorite dessert.

I eventually recovered from the shock long enough to order a panna cotta. I'm glad that I ordered that delicious vanilla custard with a nice creamy glaze/sauce on top of it. It tasted incredible and while it wasn't a zabaglione, it was good enough.

A fantastic meal!

====

Rubric: 5 = Mindblowing 4 = Excellent 3 = I see the charm 2 = Disappointing 1 = Never again
author: Eric K.

description: Gnocchi with 3 sauces: pomodoro, pesto, and gorgonzola: Gnocchi was alright. Maybe, I just don't like gnocchi's in general. Price was kind of on the steep side.
author: Vera W.

description:
my dad and i brought my fiance here for his birthday. i had read that this was a Mom & Pop type place and the reviews were so good we had to check it out. i called to make a reservation that day and the Mama got really excited when she heard my name - i guess her daughter's name is also monica. she was very chatty and warm over the phone. 

when we got to the restaurant the entire family greeted us. Papa shouted "Monica, you late!". He was decked out in a fedora and suit and generally just looking and being awesome. Mama and Papa came over and shook our hands, there were many "buona sera"s and they ushered us to our table. the place is small and cozy with hand-painted murals of ships and food on the walls. 

the menu is expansive and everything looked delicious; i decided to try the meat ravioli with porcini mushroom sauce, my dad got the special: veal & chicken with penne and my fiance got the chicken parmigiana with vegetables. 

our food came out quickly and we dug in. i LOVED my ravioli. the sauce was to die for!!! we tried each other's dishes and i think i could tell my dad and fiance were a little jealous. :P i thought my dad's pasta was great! the chicken parm was a little salty though - i'd say the pasta dishes really seemed to shine. 

we ended our meal with two selections from the dessert menu, the cheesecake with chocolate sauce and a warm custard/pudding made with marsala wine. the cheesecake was just what i needed. i thought the marsala pudding was a bit too boozy, but my dad seemed to enjoy it. 

overall, a wonderful choice for a reasonably priced, homey, delicious meal in North Beach. we will definitely be back for more.
author: Monica C.

description:
We went here because we couldn't get a reservation at Sotte Mare. The clams were great, but my Choppino was average. My husband did not like his chicken. I tasted it and it was a bit overcooked. 

The decor is casual and the restaurant has a cozy air of mom and pop restaurants. The price is super reasonable and they give you loads of food. I might go back for the comfort.
author: Judy D.

description:
Went there with a friend to what ended up to a $120 dinner. 

The place has nice cozy ambiance, the owner was hilarious and wonderful. We've had a bottle in us before we stepped in, so I can't really recall the delicious $40 white he recommended. But it was great, not too sharp or sweet like other ones I've had before. Just nice and crisp with an almost undetectable sweetness. 

The meal itself was less an exciting. The steamed clams had a very salty broth, and I've found one or two grain of either sand or unmelted salt in about one in three clams I've had. 

The seafood linguine was just alright. The sauce was definitely not homemade, it has that almost artificial sweetness that you'd find in canned sauces. If it came from a pot instead of a jar, they definitely need a new recipe. 

And the bill was a little astonishing with two entrees and one sub-par appetizer to be almost $80. Quite disappointing after reading all these great reviews.
author: Fiona S.

description: This family owned and run restaurant is a gem. You are greeted when you arrive by the nicest couple. The husband hangs out by the door and chats with everyone, and the wife serves as the waitress. The gnocchi is made fresh in the restaurant and is spectacular. The food is excellent and you cannot duplicate the family run vibe of the place. Superb.
author: Andrea K.

description:
This place is the BOMB!!  Prices are pretty steep, but it's so worth it.  The atmosphere is nice and chill (dare i say romantic?) and the people are friendly, homely, and lively.  Giuspenni is the lovely motherly figure and Francisco is the loud, obnoxious (but cool) fatherly figure. Both combine to make an excellent and unique experience not found in other restaurants.  

  It surprises me why they are not always full, but at the same time I am blessed for it allows me the pleasure to eat in comfort and peace. Other perks include no wait and the false impression that only the "cool" people eat here.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Wow, who woulda thought. Since moving to the west coast, I'd pretty much given up the idea of Italian food as a transcendental experience. Despite its location in the heart of North Beach tourist traps and astoundingly tacky decor- don't be fooled. This place is the real deal. 

The daughter will take your order and Mom cooks it up-FAST. Our dishes practically flew out of the kitchen.  My boyfriend ordered salmon with some sort of butter sauce and was practically passing out from how good it was. Dude was seriously about to lose it.  I ordered the chicken parm and was initially feeling a bit wary about it when I saw it didn't have the standard crunchy breading- a naked, thin piece of chicken lying in sauce looked kinda weird. Then I tasted it. Whatever they did to mix the sauce and cheese together was unbelievable. Definitely some next level goings-on. Plus the pasta of the day- farfalle with meat sauce was quite tasty too. 

I'd say the food here is 6 stars minus 1 star for bread being meh, decor being in need of a refresh and the owner guy being a bit scary.  This IS where I'll be taking out of towners from now on.
author: jessica s.

description: We were in North Beach and decided to stop for dinner.  After walking around a bit, I stopped and decided to check out this restaurant which had a gentleman sitting outside.  He was wearing a fedora and a big welcoming smile.  The reviews on Yelp were good and the man with the hat turned out to be Frank the owner!  We decided to give it a try and we're glad we did!  Frank sat us at a very nice table with a view of the street (great for people watching). We then met his wife, Josephine, who treated us like we very special guests in her home.  Our two sons were with us and she made sure they were comfortable and well cared for.  We felt like we had found our long lost Italian family.  Now let me tell you about the food - it matched the hospitality we received.  Homemade, prepared with love, and comforting.  We enjoyed our meal so much we didn't want to leave.  We are looking forward to going again!
author: Pamela S.

description: This is in a touristy area, but it is not a tourist trap. I've been to Italy and this is the closest I've come to feeling like I was back there. It is seriously a family joint. Dad working the door being charming and hilarious (borderline drunk and awkward too, but still fun!)  and mom and daughter working the tables. I kind of wanted to take Mom home to be my grandma.  The food is expensive if you're like me and have a hard time rationalizing spending money on pasta, but it was worth the experience.  I don't even like alfredo sauce,  but I tasted my brothers and it was fantastic. It's tiny and theres literally no place to wait for a table, but if you can get over that, I would definitely go.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Not only was the food incredible, this little family owned and operated restaurant offers some of the best service. The daughter of the owners waited on our table while their grandson was the bus boy. My heart melted when this 10 y/o or so busboy finished clearing a table and upon approaching his grandparents was showered with hugs and kisses. 
So yeah, the food... the pasta was sooooooooo fresh and my friend's salmon was cooked perfectly. Go here now... and over and over!
author: Leslie C.

description:
The Gnocchi is to die for. You must try it at least once. Perfectly puffy pillows of   potato-ey goodness = pure Heaven. 

We came here first on Independence Day without reservations but the family was very accommodating. The second time was just 2 weeks ago on a slower night but we had the same exceptional experience. The dad greets everyone as they enter, or even out on the sidewalk, and you get the double cheek European kiss-kiss, mom is running around in her orthopedic shoes and support hose supervising the kitchen, wait staff, balancing on a step stool to get more wine, etc... The wait staff is their daughters and maybe a couple of others but we had the same waitress both visits so she must live there too. They also seem to be open when other places are closed like late Sunday nights. 

I had the gnocchi both times, the first time they customized the sauce for me blending the creamy Alfredo with marinara for a nice blush sauce. The second time I went with the cream sauce with a tiny hint of the Gorgonzola cream. It is very light and melts in your mouth and doesn't give you that heavy feeling later as if you have a sack of potatoes in your stomach. It is also offered with a pesto sauce, but like I said, you can ask for any pasta with any sauce, not just what they've designated on the menu. My friends have tried the Fettuccine Alfredo, lasagna, chicken parm and all were excellent. Had a bottle of red wine the first visit, cannot remember what, but it was medium priced, recommended by the waitress and was a very good choice. The second visit, only I was drinking so I had a glass of red wine, again can't remember what, but it was good. I think at the first visit we had either the Bruschetta or the Tomato-mozzarella Caprese salad and it was excellent also. 

On to dessert... I've only tried the Tiramisu, along with my dinner companions, and it is great.... perfect creamy custard texture and the espresso flavor comes through ever so gently. Am I still talking about food?? I don't know, the sensation is too magic for words to describe. 

The bathroom is small but well kept but be warned: the walls are thin and you can hear the kitchen noise from one side and patrons talking and clinking their dishes on the other as if they are in there with you. 

OK, the place is small, but I think that is part of its appeal. It's amazing what these people do in such a tiny space, juggling tables around in the tiny triangular shaped dining room to accommodate different sized parties that walk through the door. And I love the decor, the mirrors and giant reproductions of beautiful artwork especially the breathtaking "Le Repos" by Bouguereau http://www.bouguereau.org/Le-Repos-(Rest).html 
which I seem to be lucky enough to get seated in front of each time (and lucky enough to have seen the original at the Cleveland Museum of Art ;) My second visit was the day after Christmas so they had a few delicately placed light displays and potted Poinsettias along the windowsills. Very festive but understated. Something that other places in North Beach have trouble achieving.
author: ALEXIS S.

description:
Molto Bene!

This place is as authentic North Beach/Little Italy gets.. tucked away on Columbus street with no loud signs, you'll miss it if you blink.

If you are pasta lover, then go here! The specials are always declisious, esp the paparadelle and their seafood/pesce dishes are always bountiful and full of flavor.

It's a family run business with the patriarch being quintessentially Italian. He speaks to you in Italian and broken English and is full of jokes and jabs. He loves when his customers (or his extended family) eats at his tables and enjoys their food and wine. The servers are his sons and daughters and his wife makes her rounds to make sure everyone has enough bread, water and wine. Great neighborhood spot. Don't miss it!
author: Peter K.

description: I am convinced that the Server/mother/grandmother of the place is a paid actress. As well as the Old man that is the 'owner'. They were too italian and friendly... or maybe I'm too jaded by New York by now. Please go here and order the gnocchi with pesto and the manicotti and tell me if you think they're paid actors or not... I mean they're at least in some kind of character... somebody please tell me I'm not the only one that thinks this... Oh and don't order the tiramisu...
author: Lindsey J.

description: Lovely place in little Italy to share with good friends. I went on New Years Eve. Delicious food and the owner is very nice. Neat looking place too! Looking forward to going back.
author: Eva B.

description: Love this place! The daily special is always an incredible choice. This is at the top of my list for a great meal and friendly atmosphere!
author: Christina A.

description: A great family run neighborhood restaurant! One night we were craving Clam Linguine or some sort of pasta, something hearty for the chilly weather. After roaming Columbus and reading yelp reviews on our phones, we can across Franchino. We were greeted by the owner we rushed to open the door for us. SO CUTE. The restaurant was cute and cozy. We were seated right away and our food came out very promptly. The clam linguine was exactly what we had been craving. My dish was a pasta with pancetta in a tomato sauce. Simple, yet delicious. Will totally be back, the family that runs this restaurant is just too adorable not to! :)
author: lauren j.

description: This place is so so so Italian! There is this guy there all the time that I think is actually Franchino he runs the show and he's really friendly.  Its pretty small and always has a lot of people and very warm inside.  It can be a little loud but it's all part of the fun Italian atmosphere.  One time I was there at some point they turned the lights low and one of the servers started singing opera he was pretty good!  This is a great place to take someone why want the authentic North Beach experience  but with decent food too!
author: Marlene S.

description: This is the second time we've been to this restaurant, and both times it has been outstanding.  Tonight we had the ravioli with porcini mushroom sauce - excellent - and tortellini with pesto.  The pesto was very fresh tasting with nice garlic flavor.
author: Steve P.

description: This is the real deal, as many of the reviews have stated. We were greeted warmly by owner. He seated us right by the window near the door--the best seat in my opinion--as you can see people walking by outside and you have your own private dining area. The food was fantastic--I tried the Veal Saltimbocca. Excellent! The wait staff were attentive and friendly. The ambiance is quite nice--down home--and you can tell it is family-owned. My partner has Salmon and it was amazingly seasoned well. Definitely we will be coming back. If you park in the garage under the Hilton, it is a short walk.
author: Ron P.

description: The best italian food as well as service I have ever had. The food wasso good and the hospitality was even better! Def. Coming back next time I'm in town
author: Pol S.

description: Loved this place.  The whole family works there.  The father was very cute greetings us outside and bringing us in.  We were fortunate to have "Momma" wait on us in the beginning.  She gave us a great tip on wine that would go with our meal.  We had the risotto pescador and the prawns in red sauce.  The fish was so fresh and the sauce on both were great. The sauce on the prawns though was memorable...so many layers of flavor that worked perfectly with the prawns.  The prawns were the best that I ever had.  So, tender and flavorfull.  Will be back my next trip.
author: Loki A.

description:
Everything about this place is great, except for its location in touristy North Beach. 

It's a family-run business, and you'll see Mama Josephine in her housewifey costume greeting you at the door, and Papa Didn't-Catch-His-Name waiting on your table in a strangely warm yet robot-like methodical manner. Apparently he's the chef, but she makes a lot of the pasta. Their daughter also waits on tables there. The place is all painted in Rococo blues & pinks, which somehow works.

I had the fettuccine with salmon and asparagus. The fettuccine was excellent, the kind of tender bite that you only get from fresh, homemade pasta. I also tasted my friends' gnocchi, which was out of this world, and ravioli, which was also fantastic. 

For appetizers we had the melted cheese and roasted red peppers thing, which are, like, my two all-time favorite foods, so I was delighted. Also the caprese salad, which had perfect fresh mozzarella that was soft, not rubbery. 

The house chianti lubricated everything quite nicely.
author: Melinda K.

description:
Amazing Itlalian food at reasonable prices. The family running the place is a hoot. 

Parking can be challenging here, so consider cabbing it.
author: Matt W.

description: Absolutely wonderful! Visiting from Los Angeles and couldn't have found a better place. Extremely friendly, homemade, and DELICIOUS! Highly recommended.
author: E H.

description: The food is wonderful! The atmosphere is comfortable and home-like. The service is great and friendly!!! We had never been there before but the web reviews were great and this place really lives up to the reviews! I had the capellini with chicken and shrimp with the pink sauce-so good! I also agree that the bruschetta is very flavorful! You will not be disappointed if you go here. Just don't be surprised with the setting-it's a small restaurant so it can get crowded. Get there early.  Also the bathroom is very very small.  But the food and service makes this place definitely worth it!!!
author: C H.

description:
I've enjoyed eating at Franchino since I first arrived in town.  Franco sings and dances with the ladies.  His wife serves the food.  His daughter sprinkles the parmesan cheese on your plate.  The Pasta Pescadore is very nice either with cream or tomato sauce.  
Let him order for you and don't act surprised when the check comes. 
It's all part of the show.
author: Kev M.

description: excellent local italian restaurant: Loved this place. The ambiance, food, and service was excellent. This is a true Italian restaurant in North Beach that delivers on all fronts. A must visit.
author: Que T.

description:
My friend came from out of town, and she wanted Italian food. We went to Franchino (my first time there) after seeing the reviews here and checking out the menu online. I wanted to go somewhere with a wide variety of pasta dishes, because I never know what I'm craving.

When we got to the restaurant, the owner told us that there was a 5 minute wait. He was totally apologetic, and since it was a Saturday night, we were expecting to wait anyways. It's a relatively small, but comfy atmosphere. It's a family-run business. We ordered the Risotto Pescatora and Linguine con Vongole (seafood risotto and linguine with clams). We didn't have to wait long for the food. The risotto was delicious and there was a mix of salmon, squid, clams, shrimp, and mussels in the risotto. The salmon was nice and soft. The linguine came with a white wine sauce, and you can taste the wine, but it wasn't overpowering. 

The seafood pasta dishes were about $17, and most other pasta dishes were about $14-15. Overall, the food was delicious, and the owner was incredibly friendly (and funny). He was singing and dancing to the music, and was a great host. We got a the double-cheek kiss from him when we left. We didn't get to try to tiramisu because we were stuffed. I will definitely be going back.
author: Ring K.

description:
One word:generic. 

I knew not expect anything too mind blowing from a place on the tourist stripe of North Beach but this was seriously the archtype of bland basic Italian for tourists place.

Was the food edible, yes. was it tasty, not so much. was it interesting or worth going back to? not at all.

Price wise it ranges from 12 to 20 which seems pretty good until you realize how average and boring the food is. I got the veal marsala (19 dollars) and it was four small piece that weren't that tender and frankly the whole point of veal is how tender it is. My wife got the ravoli porcini which was just ravoli in red cream sauce with a tiny amount of porcini mushrooms.(15).

we had bruchetta to start with which was pretty plain and a chocolate cover canoli which was the best things we had.

It was 60 dollar meal that tasted like a 20 dollar meal at the Olive Garden. It the type of place you take people who have never eaten real Italian food or who like the Olive Garden to dinner when they visit from small town USA.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
Ok, so maybe the 5 stars is pushing it - this is not what I'd call "fine dining", and their wine list is a little sparse, but as far as service and ambiance are concerned, Franchino's is top notch.  

1st off - Franchino and his family are the sweetest and most friendly people ever. Since my 1st time coming, I've always been greeted very warmly, and after many repeat visits they become even more friendly - which almost seems impossible. 

2ndly - if you want good, quality, tasty Italian meals on the more casual side of things, this is the place. How people can patronize places like Olive Garden (YUCK!) when you could spend about the same amount of money and get something authentic and fresh is just beyond me.

Lastly - this place is quaint, cozy, and a romantic in a sort of "Lady and the tramp meets San Francisco/North Beach" kind of way. I personally love it for a 1st date spot, or one of those places you return to over and over again for casual romantic little evenings. 

Even more lastly - Franchino is a REALLY funny guy, if he has a glass of wine or two, you're in for some opera, dancing and all manner of fun times. 

TWO THUMBS UP!!!
author: Marco M.

description:
The ambiance was great- the vintage clothes with Italy on the table set the mood. We came in pretty early- around 5pm and the waitresses were sooooo very helpful. We got bread right way, our glasses of water were never empty, and one of the women talked to us about her home town in Italy. 

The food was phenomenal! I had the chicken marsala- very thin slices of chicken but a lot of them- 5 i think, with a delicious sauce. You can choose vegetables or pasta for the side and I chose the pasta- and boy am I glad i did! It was a simple tomato sauce pasta but it was super delicious. My boyfriend had the special- pasta in a tomato sauce with gorgonzola cheese, veal, and chicken. THIS WAS HEAVEN!!! SO YUMMY! It was a nice sized portion too. 

No complaints here. The prices were average (about 15-20 a plate), the people there were wonderful, and the food- superb. Must try!
author: Sarita M.

description: Great Service! I loved being greeted at the door when we arrived (Older Italian gentleman, probably the owner?) The food was really good, I had pappardelle pasta with Italian sausage and a tomato based sauce. It was excellent, I practically licked my plate clean. For dessert, I had a cannoli perhaps one of the best ever. We got there before it became totally packed. It reminded me of what a gem North Beach can be in the way of Italian food.
author: G F.

description: Great dinner tonite!   Great service.  I just told Franchinos daughter what I wanted ( not even on menu) and she made it for me!!  We are always treated like family when we go there.
author: Jer G.

description: The pasta and sausage with mushrooms was so good I cried.  I am 61; that has never happened before!
author: M R.

description:
I would come back to San Francisco for this restaurant alone. We took a cab to North Beach and had passed this on the way. the cab driver recommended it and Yelp had some pretty good reviews... so we walked up to check out the menu... as soon as we did the owner, (Franchino, himself?) popped out in a fedora and suit and ushered us in. We walked in and this place is about the size of my hotel bathroom, and decorated in everything italian. This worked out well because my husbands family is 100% italian. We were seated, and the daughter, Monica, was our waitress, who began explaining the specials, or rather "what Mom made special tonight." We all ordered the minestrone soup, which came out and they put a hefty spoonful of parmegiano cheese. This was lick your bowl clean kinda soup. The bread is in fact a little weak, but still good. We ordered the eggplant parm, the frutti di mare, the papperdelle and sausage special and the ravioli. The ravioli's were handmade and boy did they just melt in your mouth. I didn't want the dish to end... my husbands eggplant wasn't overly cooked and the sausage was delicious. Compared to other places and living in Vegas, this place is extremely budget friendly. 
They make an amazing meal and you won't be dissapointed with the quality of the food. Mmm, my mouth is watering just thinking about it!
author: Kim D.

description: A restaurant with a real family feel. Small and intimate, with great decorative touches (wine bottles piled up to the ceiling, great big murals). Delicious food--I had this seafood pasta dish--which had delightful presentation and tasted great. All in all, I'd certainly return.
author: Miles S.

description: Tremendous Mom & Pop place - literally. The Mom makes all the dishes, Pop is the host that entertains (and sings!). Their daughters are the great waitresses. Six of us had all different dishes, they were all amazing. All the pasta is home made. Take the staff's recommendations, and start with the Bruschetta.
author: Wally T.

description: Family ran cute little Italian restaurant. Service is decent; especially the dad has the charisma to greet the guest. The food is average, I think I can make better. Not much selection of wine, the crowd are mostly tourists. With the $$ you pay, there are so many other choices in the city. Like a16, bambino....not worth it!
author: ivy h.

description:
REVISED:
The more we visit Franchino's, the more we appreciate the down home cooking.  We've tried their cannolini (excellent) & pasta with shrimp (also delish) as well as all our other mainstays.

The owner is super friendly & we never have to wait no matter how late we stroll in.  Sniff, sniff...we will miss you Franchino's!


ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Another solid, family-run Italian restaurant in North Beach.  This place has great pasta dishes.  My husband & I have tried the pasta primavera, penne with bolognese sauce, gnocchi, & chicken parmigiana, & we've never been disappointed.  Their soups (minestrone & strateccelli) are good as well, & all the portions are just right.

This place makes it as one of our top three in NB!
author: Jenny M.

description:
There are a lot of reasons why I love this place, have come back repeatedly, and have had just about everything on the menu at least once... 

Tops on this list: the atmosphere, the fresh quality of the food, and you can always trust their recommendations!

I really like that this place isn't presumptuous at all. There's pictures of the family on the walls, lot's of homey touches, and they've decorated for the Holiday season.  

If you have questions about something on the menu or a pairing, they'll gladly explain it to you and not make you feel dumb for asking (like some other places).  You end up learning a lot about the food and how it's made. 

The bread is hit-or-miss, but I would advise against filling up on the bread and appetizers *anyway* because there's freshly made pasta in exquisite sauce on the way!  Save room! 

As someone who is very picky about my Italian food,  I wouldn't come here over and over if I didn't think it was worth it.  

The owner Franco is loud, but I didn't find him abrasive or rude.  He pretty-much just sings with the Italian opera playing over the speakers and chats with the patrons... I found it charming.

I had my Birthday dinner here the last 2 years and Farewell dinner here before I moved from SF back east to NH.  My guests were all extremely pleased and everyone had a great time :)

Enjoy!
author: Carrie B.

description:
Absolutely one of our favorite restaurants in SF. A true family restaurant, and the food is sooo good. And one of the grandson's (he's just nine) has joined the staff - you feel like you're at home at Franchino!
A rare treat is when Papa gives patrons a rendition of O Sole Mio. The scamorza (smoked mozz) is out of this world, and over the years I've had the gnocchi, mushroom ravioli, pasta primevera... all fabulous. A very decent wine list too.
author: Rachel F.

description: The food was ok but do not believe they take reservations. They took our reservation last night and it meant nothing.  My veal was tasty but nothing special.  The eggplant was average.  The calamari salad was delicious however.
author: Dan P.

description: Went back again for the same dish and experience..eekk..totally lacking. The clam juice was super salty and dry - not enough for me to dip my bread. I order some pasta with this "aurora" sauce which really it's just tomatoe cream sauce with dry chicken & shrimp. - the flat wasn't even big and it cost $18.  Everything was just dry that day. I don't even remember what my date got - I guess it was that unmemorable. Therefore, I am not pleased or happy. There are tons of restaurants along Columbus, I will not return here and go somewhere else.
author: Yum Y U M.

description: The bread was cold and stale.  Hoping that the entrees would be better, we were disappointed with the gnocchi.  It really didn't have any flavor and had a rubbery texture.  However, the chicken parmgiana was really good, with lots of melted cheese and nicely grilled veggies.
author: Rose C.

description: Nice family run Italian resturant on Columbus Ave. Food was above average traditional Italian. As another reviewer noted, the bread was forgettable, but the food and family charm of this place made up for it.
author: Chris C.

description:
The restaurant is definitely family owned - a charming Italian man opened the door for us, as if greeting us into his home.  The decor is very cozy, definitely making you feel as if you are a guest over for dinner.

The menu seems very comprehensive - if you like Italian food, it doesn't seem likely that you won't be able to find it on here.   I had the manicotti, and tried a bit of the pesto and eggplant parmesan that my friends had ordered.  However, I thought that the food was pretty plain and generic tasting.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't as amazing as I had hoped for.   The portions also seemed a bit on the small side.

All in all, it was alright, but I probably wouldn't go back any time soon.
author: Thomas S.

description: The restaurant smelled musty--like an old unkept grandma's house. Food was unremarkable and the bread was stale. Walk on by and go to the Rose Pistola for an amazing meal instead.
author: K G.

description:
First Five Star I have given and the reason is simple. It is food with love and you can feel the love from the moment you walk in.

Luckily, we beat the dinner rush and we were able to be seated, but it would have been worth the wait.

Started off rocky, ordering two bottles of wine, except they were out of the second one. After the third try, we were able to get a second bottle that they had in stock. Because of the headache, they brought us a bruschetta as an apology for the mission, which added to family love and atmosphere. 

As for the food, you are not eating food from a cook. Instantly, you will notice the mother walking around and you can notice her necklace, with a black and white photo of her mother with a red ribbon. Simply put, you are dining on a legacy of cooking, recipes, and flavors passed through generations and yet still preserved heritage. 

Craving veal parm, but had to try to the special. Forgot the name, but it was a long flat homemade pasta with italian sausage with a light and flavorful tomato cream sauce. The mother proudly told me her recipe, including how she hand-makes the pasta in the morning with her granddaughter and her secret to cream sauce..... pinch of gorgonzola cheese. 

As we were eating, our neighbors were onto their desserts and the sight of this hand-dipped chocolate cannoli stopped me mid-sentence. Spying on your neighbors gastrofeast is a good precusor, but when you see a chain reaction of people ordering the same dessert and saying.. "I want that!"... is amazing.  Even as we got ours, we can see our new neighbords eyeballing my cannoli like a crack addiction.  Unfortunately, it was soo good, that it ruined all other cannolis for me now. 

The food is amazing and comes with the pride of an Italian heritage that truly loves putting smiles around the dinner table while making people fat, just like any lovable italian grandmother. The uniqueness comes from a woman who loves what she does, creating strong family bonds through the pallete, but yet loves to share her knowledge. It is rare that a business oozes a family atmosphere as a priority instead of profitability, and it is much appreciated when this atmosphere triggers nostalgic memories. That is the power of food with love. 

Franchino, Thank You.
author: John S.

description:
This place is definitely over hyped, food was so-so. 
Their chicken parmigiana was bland, the chicken itself was tough.
My friend's gnocchi gorgonzola was disappointing, too.

We planned to order some dessert but after getting those kind of food, we'd better to go & got dessert from other great restaurant.
author: Natalie S.

description: Big fan - it was my first time, i had the arribiata - fresh and delicious! staff was friendly and entertaining! good table wine too!
author: Lucy M.

description: Friendly service (personally attended to by the owners), great wine recommendations, fabulous rustic cooking with homemade pastas. Delicious osso buco and ragus, great gnocchis, wonderful and warm atmosphere. Would recommend for quiet romantic dinner out.
author: Y K.

description:
I love this place.    I love Franchino and his family, who make the dining experience such a pleasure, it feels like you're surrounded by family --but not MY family, which really increases the pleasure quotient ;-).

Franchino is extremely helpful when you're not sure what to choose, and knows exactly which bottle of wine to recommend (we had picked out one wine, and he said no, and actually picked out a less expensive wine that would go better with our food).

The gnocci with gorgonzola sauce is so good you'll crave it for days afterward.  The calimari salad is perfect to split as an appetizer.

His wife or his daughter will come and take your order and they are both wonderful.  The entire family goes out of their way to make you feel like a very special guest.  I highly recommend Franchino.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Franchinos is all about the man. My wife had me take her here for her b-day back when we were dating.  I had visited a number of Italian spots in The City, but no experience quite like this. 

Very small, little worn and can be crowded, but the atmosphere makes it homey. 

First stop brushchetta, ask for a wine selections, tons of great bottles for $20 or less. Pasta melts the mouth, almost always order parpadelle, and be sure and save room for house made zambaglione, the Marsala wine custard with like a dozen egg yolks and a pound of sugar...... had to roll us out of there, but was ready to roll back in anytime. We returned recently with my 10 year old son, no stranger to restaurants, prefers sushi to meat. He proclaimed it "best meal ever" 

 Franchino sings, if you're lucky might fight with his wife in Italian (until one of his daughter's tells him to pipe down) then sings some more. A definitely "only in SF experience.
author: Thomas W.

description:
We went here after my great Aunt Rose's rosary. It was the perfect ambiance to remember a sweet little Sicilian lady...since she lived right around the corner on Lombard. 

My Dad ordered the best dish...Home made spinach and ricotta ravioli with Porcini Mushroom Sauce. The sauce was velvety and rich so that we thought perhaps they used veal or beef stock. (They didn't) The porcinis were not those dried bits of fungus sometimes ridden with worms...I think they were frozen or freeze dried...very good quality. I had the eggplant Parmesan with rigatoni. Delicious, but I prefer my eggplant parm with a touch of bechamel...The cheese seemed a little rubbery...I hope they didn't microwave it...( It was unbelievably hot)

We enjoyed the entire meal with really loud Italian pop music blaring (and skipping), a bottle of excellent Primitivo, and fine service from our owner/host, and his lovely wife... I would go back to try the gnocchi.
author: Eliza K.

description:
If you are looking for a relaxed and delightful Italian meal-complete with silly dancing Italian owners and the most amazing pasta and tiramisu around- this is the place. The atmosphere is unassuming, but the food the best  Italian I've had in the city. I love this place and am currently planning to have my boyfriend's next birthday here.
try the tiramisu, the penne arrabiata, and the panacotta
author: SJ P.

description: There's this place Italian place in Reno (yes, Reno) I consider the best Italian food on the west coast. Franchino is on par with that place. Family run, small, and you have a feeling that the recipes are recipes the owner ate when he was a kid. Skip over the commercial places and eat here. You'll be glad you did.
author: Bruce B.

description:
DO NOT GO INTO THE MONA LISA!

It's tough to make a trip to Franchino's and actually get in there if you haven't been there. Be on the look out for people beckoning you in, that's probably the wrong place.

Franchino's is freakin awesome. The pasta is homemade, I spoke with one of the owners while I was there tonight and she told me all about how she makes the pasta at her house and brings it into the restaurant. EVERYTHING we had was delicious. Lambrusco(check) Minestrone(check) Cheese Dish Appetizer Thing (check) pesto gnocchi(check) house special salmon pasta with pink sauce (extra check) tiramisu(double extra check) Espresso(check and check).

Ultimately I will come back to this place over and over again, for the food, but also for the antics of the husband and the warmth and friendliness of the wife. This couple has owned the restaurant for almost 20 years and they are still going strong. LOVE IT!
author: Jenni C.

description: I brought friends to Franchino based on the Yelp reviews as the "best" North Beach Italian Restaurant.  Was OK, but not the "4 Stars" on Yelp.  Wine was surprisingly bad, especially for NorCal. Service was very good, but decor was mediocre and the food undistinguished.  Four of us each had different dishes; none of them especially good.  Bruschetta was nice, as were the grilled vegetables they offered as an alternative to a side of pasta with my Chicken Parmigan.
author: Jeff W.

description:
We had a reservation for a group of 6, which was made 2 weeks prior, and like the other postings say, it really doesn't matter.  As we waited for the rest of our party to show up and watched the small dining room fill up I was wondering if there was a magic VIP room that he was going to put us in.  Nope, we just had to wait 25 minutes after the ressie to sit.  Okay.

So the table that sat right after we did had wine and an appetizer before we even had our drink order taken.  Little annoyed.  The owner is boisterous and comically in a rough, Italian sort of way which wavered between entertaining and annoying.  We only got one of the two bottles of wine we ordered and he had to return to the table to say he missed an entree.  

We were really, really hungry so I don't even remember if the appetizers were good.  I think the bruschetta and caprese salad were pretty standard.  We had read good things about the gnocchi so most of us got that.  I had the tomato sauce and the others did all three sauces, which I regretted not doing.  The white sauce was the best (creamy yet slightly cheesy), then the pesto, then the tomato.  The gnocchi was fluffy and delicious, but nothing I would make the trip back to have again. Apparently the chicken Parmesan was fantastic, but I can't say I had a bite.

It was hard to get the attention of the waiter/owner so it was a struggle to get water refills, get our other bottle of wine, the check, etc.  We started working through the bus boy and the nice older lady that worked there which was a much less stressful option.  We opted to go to another location for dessert for this reason.  It was good, but nothing past that.  I would like to try Mona Lisa next door with the crazy huge menu next time I am craving Italian cuisine.
author: Erin H.

description:
So, it's really hard to distinguish all the Italian restaurants on Columbus from one another. On the rare journey to north beach, I'm just as likely to wind up at one as I am the other. 

A friend and I wandered into Franchino's by complete chance the other night, and I was pleasantly surprised. I have a soft spot for family run businesses, and the family that runs Franchino's was warm and engaging- tripping over each other in the small space, but running around making sure everyone in the restaurant was being taken care of. (3 different people came to check on us through the course of our meal.) The food was tasty, and despite being a little small and crowded, the atmosphere was fun.
author: Kristen M.

description:
This place is amazing.

Definitely a small, family run place--as soon as the owner seated us--an older Italian man wearing a fedora, he tells us, "My wife will serve you soon". This is definitely a lot personal than "Your server will be with you soon". The servers were great, personable, friendly, and the host even went to shake my hand and open the door for us as we left. 

The food is great. We had a place of proscuito and soft parmesan cheese that was really great. My girlfriend had a dish of stuffed cannoli, but even better was my plate of home made pasta and Italian sausage--the sauce and sausage were great, but the home made, thick cut egg noodles were the star of the show.

It is definitely pricier than the Olive Garden, with most pasta dishes ranging between $15 and $20, but nothing unreasonable or what I would call expensive, and the quality of the food is worth it.

The place is definitely small. Everything is painted pink--the walls, the ceiling, even the front door. It would be a good idea to go early in the evening--we went around 5 pm, and had quick service, because it can be packed later on in the evening. 

I will definitely come again next time I visit North Beach.
author: Eric J.

description:
Yum. I took my sister visiting from Chicago (where Italian food is great, and EVERYWHERE) to Franchino tonight. I was slightly skeptical based on the goofy portraits on the walls and the tables adorned with linens with the map of Italy. It is also quite small and a bit noisy.

That said... I had a 7PM reservation for 2, and got our table at exactly 7PM (which is when we walked in the door). That alone gets the place some stars - this city is full of places that can't seem to seat you at or near your reservation time. Pet peeve.

The wait staff and owner were friendly and attentive, and yes, they spoke Italian! Always a good sign. 

We shared a house salad and split two entrees (a cheese manacotti special and the chicken marsala). Both were VERY good, and also the portions were just right. We finished everything and felt satisfied - not stuffed like the manacotti. We even had room for dessert - the panacotta. Nice... not fantastic, but nice.

Anyway, Franchino has an extensive menu, a small (but decent) wine list, and a homey ambiance. I am glad to have tried it, and I will definitely go back!

Oh, and like other reviewers have said before... what's up with the bread? Not good. But you know, that's okay in the end. I didn't stuff myself with bread and then not have room for my entree!
author: Angie J.

description:
Feeling a bit depressed, I decided to treat myself to a nice dinner in North Beach.  I'd never been to this restaurant, but the menu looked good and the prices were reasonable.

What a surprise and delight when I sat down to my meal!

First, although dining alone, I was greeted enthusiastically by the owner and given a very desirable table by the window.  This restaurant seats only 25 and it was well attended so the nice seating was really appreciated.

This is family - mama, papa and daughter.  They obviously enjoy working together and put on a show for the customers.  Lots of restaurants advertise that they treat you like a guest in their home -- this one delivers.

The food was much better than good, if not spectacular.  I ordered a seafood pasta that was beautifully prepared.  The Panacotta for desert (personally prepared and served by Mama) was perfect.

The service was excellent, unrushed and warm.

This place is a keeper!
author: Charles K.

description: This was THE BEST meal of our trip! Fantastic quaint atmosphere; the owner himself greets you at the door-LOVED it!  Go early for ease in getting a table.
author: Janie B.

description: This review is long overdue! My fiance and I have been coming here for four years and have always had a great experience. We bring all of our out-of-town visitors here and they love it as well. It's so cozy with such a nice, authentic Italian family vibe. If you're lucky, Franchino might even sing an old Italian song for the entire restaurant :) Can't wait for our next out-of-towners to visit!
author: Lizette R.

description:
I love this place!  I went to Italy this past summer and enjoyed the authentic Italian food and wine.  I was really spoiled over there by the freshness and quality of the food.  When I got back to the United States, I was so disappointed with the Italian food here....until I went to Franchino's.  Once I walked through the door and was greeted by Franco (the owner), I felt like I was back in the trattorias in Italy.  The place is cute and cozy, and the atmosphere is great.  Service was excellent because they are very attentive.  And we certainly did get hooked up with some good antipasta, too.  Everyone cleaned their plates.  Definitely date-worthy, and a good place to go with friends and family as well.  

** Just a little tip:  The restaurant is fairly small, so if you're planning to go there for dinner, make sure to definitely get there before 7:00 pm  because it gets packed quickly.
author: JulieAnne L.

description:
I appreciate the reviews on yelp and have come to rely on them when selecting restaurants. Franchino was no exception and the positive reviews were right on - especially the one about the owner singing and carrying on. It's very entertaining and makes for a more interesting dining experience.

The Pesto was fabulous out of the 5 people in our party, EVERYONE loved their dishes.

I would have to give it a few negative points: 

1) $16 corkage fee - that's little steep for the caliber restaurant
2) Basket of bread is pretty bland - I expected better when considering the main course
3) This place is tiny - we were sitting inches away from the party next to us! I wouldn't recommend for large parties of more than 5 or 6.

Other than that, the entrees are reasonable priced and the food is really good!
author: Shira R.

description:
This is another quality Italian restaurant in the city - family owned & operated.

If you are within shouting distance, Franco will help you find it (follow the Italian Opera music).

Franchino's is never obscenely crowded despite its intimate atmosphere.

I suggest ordering the eggplant and gorgonzola appetizer (not on the menu) and the gnocchi and fettucini franchino for pasta dishes.
author: Jason N.

description:
I, like many others am constantly on a quest for new interesting restaurants that provide a home for progressive culinary endeavors.  However, the one style of cooking that I just need to have as traditional as possible is Italian.

What's better on a cold nor-cal evening than a perfectly seasoned home made rotini with red sauce, sauteed zucchini and peppers and zesty savory italian sausage dripping with olive oil and concentrated love.  I went with the girlfriend and her family and we all shared.  But the aforementioned pasta primavera was without question the most incredible dish of the evening.  Though the chicken piccata was immensely delicious, not the butter overload that most places have.  Last but not least, the house white was an incredibly refreshing pinot grigio that replenished the soul.

The only thing that this place needs for a 5 star is more seating.  But perhaps the homey atmosphere adds to that traditional flavor I like.
author: Ethan B.

description: My sister felt like trying something and some place NEW; that doesn't happen often so anytime it does, it's reason enough to celebrate!! After looking at a few menus of nearby and next-door restaurant, we decided to enter here instead where, upon sitting in a TiGhT corner next to the ice-box, I noticed a cloth tablecloth showing Sardinia - finally I could show my sister where I was for almost two years!! Ordered a sauteed Calamari with Spaghetti ($14.95) in a tomato sauce of garlic and basil, while sis opted for the Spaghetti Carbonara ($14.95) served with ham, parmigiano cheese and eggs in a white sauce. She ate that up right away and my paste with squid was okay. The sauce however was excellent. I thought my dish was heated too hot (very) due to the calamari being stuck together. I was otherwise happy that the amount of calamari was quite plentiful. I agree with others in that the bread was stale, but I still used it to mop up as much of the tomato sauce as possible ~ that's how good it tasted! This all went down great with the house white wine, followed by a cappuccino that was enough to keep me awake for a few days!! aaaaaaaah...  ;-)  Sis also tried the tiramisu (see shaky pix) and at $6.95 a pop, it was small but very tasty! The whole restaurant looks very typical southern Italia....  the bathroom looked quite small. I wouldn't mind returning again.....  It was past 6pm on Wednesday when I drove by the opposite direction an seeing a parking spot right in front, executed a clean quick illegal u-turn!! Otherwise, no parking except for what you might find on the street....
author: Tony L.

description: Very nice people - very nice food - very nice prices - thank you Franco!
author: Jeff W.

description: We have been to Francino's about a dozen times with family and friends. It never has disappointed. The food is all home made, Francino is a great host and Mrs. is wonderful. I most often ask either of them to place my order for me and I have enjoyed every meal. This is a casual, home like experience. If you are looking for formality, go elsewhere.
author: mark k.

description: The food here was good. The place itself small and nicely decorated. I had the Parmigiana Di Melanzane and it was alright and my girlfriend had some sort of cheese ravioli and it was A-OK. The pasta was freshly made, at least I can say that. We ordered the cheesecake for desert and it was mediocre. The owner was very welcoming and friendly ....to all other guests except for us. Then he went around conversing with customers at every table except for our table. I guess it isn't too often two lesbians come around to eat at this spot. Good/okay food & homophobic owner. Overpriced for the quality of food. I won't be back . Take your business elsewhere.
author: L G.

description: Good service and is not very expensive.  But the food is just so so. My girlfriend got a spicy pasta and it was super spicy. A warning would have been nice. Tiramisu was amazing.
author: Ron O.

description:
franchino and his wife are geniuses.  in north beach you have to do something as an italian restaurant to "stand out".  what do they do?  franchino sings.  every now-and-again through the course of the evening he will lower the lights, make a short poetic speech about some lovely lady in the restaurant, bring that lovely lady up and serenade her.  if that's not entertaining enough, if you can find the wife (who is usually working near the bar section of the restaurant) and look at the expression on her face as he does this....it adds to the show.  she could chew nails every time he does it.  i'm surprised franchino doesn't suffer more black eyes.

the entertainment aside, this restaurant reminds me of something you'd see in an italian movie.  it's like the family all got together for dinner and grandma is doing the cooking.  i liked some items better than others....in particular, the "house alfredo" turned out to be the ultimate in tastiness.  best thing was we were able to make an evening out of our trip to franchino's vs. just having dinner.  you can't say that about too many restaurants.

TIP:  i had read in a previous yelp the wine selection was not all that good.  since we were in wine country prior to our stay in san francisco we picked up a bottle of wine for our dinner at franchino's.  their corking fee was $18.00.  the bottle of wine we bought had only been $15.00.  if you're taking your own wine sneak it in with a flask.  but I have to say i took a look at their wine list and their wine selection wasn't that bad and was pretty well suited for the type of food they serve.  so you might consider just going with what they offer.  

i'd also recommend reservations.....it can get crowded.

our evening ended with a hug from franchino and his wife as we were leaving the restaurant.  it was dinner at our italian families house with grandma doing the cooking.
author: Mike Q.

description:
Great environment, friendly attentive family and a lot of style. 

Most Italian places kill you with an obscene amount of pasta, but the portions here are just right.
author: Lilea E.

description: Had a really good meal here. Great service, great atmosphere, very Italian. The owner was cracking me up giving crazy speeches all night. Fun
author: Shooter M.

description: I think that this is my favorite Italian restaurant in the city.  This family run gem always makes you feel at home and the food is absolutely delicious.  The pastas are fresh and are wonderfully balanced in spice, flavor and depth.  We have brought many friends from out of town here and they have loved the place too.
author: David R.

description: I came in for lunch and had penne with a tomato cream sauce. The help was very nice and the food was good but did not blow me away.
author: david c.

description:
My husband took me here for Valentine's day and had the same meal when we went the first time and we still think it's the best italian place in North Beach. 
The Chicken Saltinbocca reminds me of eating a really good salt and pepper crab. Juicy and very tasty. I tried my husbands Chicken Posillipo a simple chicken and tomatoes dish, great for the non-dairy eaters is still delicious.
It's one of the places that we definately eat everything that's in our plate. Just writing about it makes my mouth water.
author: Diane M.

description:
Two things up front:  1) I'm from suburban Philadelphia and grew up eating great Italian-American food (both homecooked and in restaurants).  2) When we eat out now, it's usually with our 2-year old daughter, so I am sensitive to how restaurants treat families with small children.

We had a wonderful experience at Franchino tonight.  When we arrived, they were packed, and I was nervous about trying to squeeze around a small table with our daughter.  But the staff made room for us and we were fine.  They treated our daughter like a little princess.  She is well-behaved at restaurants, so that helps, but it was nice that they were willing to bring her a small plate of pasta early on so we could get  her eating right away.

The food is good.  Basic, but *good*.  The tomato sauce is just lovely-- flavorable, fresh, not too heavy.  We literally cleaned our plates.  This was just our first visit, so of course I can't comment on a wide range of dishes, but everything was delicious.  The bruschetta plate was some of the best I've ever had.  

The staff-- all family-- were friendly and efficient.  It has a warm atmosphere.  We will definitely come back AND I will certainly bring my parents here when they visit from Philly.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
I found this small family owned Italian restaurant by reading reviews on yelp(of course) and  decided to take my family here for a dinner celebration for Father's Day and my graduation from college. 

I made reservations for  7 on Friday at 7:00 but my family is of course the slowest so I called to change it to 8. They hostess which is of course the daughter was said they could still take us and would do their best to accommodate my party. 
The only downfall of course is the North beach parking situation. It is horrible and I would take a star away because its unbelievable and no one could be on-time for a reservation in that area but the ambiance and great food made up for it.

My family had the best experience here! The family is so hilarious and sweet and the food was incredibly good! My dad had the veal Marsala and cheese tortellini, my mom and brother had the seafood pescatora, and my two sister's and I had this dish (I wish I could remember the name of) that had mushrooms, chicken, prawns, and garlic with your choice of tomato, or cream sauce. (I had the cream and my sisters had the tomato:) All of the dishes were delicious and the conversations between our hostess and our table were wonderful. 

My whole family will return to this great restaurant and invite more to come along!
author: Tishina B.

description:
I love the people who own the place. They are so nice. I love love love the home made pasta with home made sausages!! 

The wine selection is really good as well.

You have to go early to get a good seat. It's a small place but very cozy.
author: Do L.

description: Nice little italian place, the food and service were ok.
author: Veronica M.

description: Visited this place on a whim in 2002 when family was in town.  It's still there and will be there as long as Franco cares to be in the restaurant business.  This is classic family-owned in North Beach, and it is a testament when I was in there to find homesick Italians eating while they were in SF on vacation (Italians are actually never far from their motherland's food, in all its regional varieties).  Can go right with most things on the menu, you'll miss it in North Beach if you think that all the places on Columbus are tourist traps...
author: Todd S.

description: I tested it yesterday with some friends, the food was OK but this is not the best Italian experience I had in SF...
author: Thibaut L.

description:
puttanesca pooty tooty that was good.
the pasta puttanesca, sorry. yeah, that was really great. super. and even though the upstairs is tiny and cramped, its a great location and the view is great. the waiter was all suave and italian and awesome.
author: Joanne S.

description: basic cheesy chicken alfredo pasta...chicken breast slicings...slightly bland and near solid thick saucing...bit premium pricing for simple pasta selection...enjoying $twenty-nine bottle pinot grigio more...fair pricing wine options...simple list picking...favorite being mushroom risotto...thick blob of 'shroom deliciousness...
author: Hen A.

description: A group of 7 of us wandered by and were immediately drawn to this cozy, family run friendly place.  We enjoyed the great service, first greeted by Mr. Franchino and then seated by his wife and waited on by both Mrs. Franchino and his daughter.  We ordered antipasto for the group and were amazed at the 3 plate spread for all of us to try various delicious homemade samples.  We felt like we were in the dining room of the Franchino's as their honored guests.  We will be back for sure - bringing other friends and family to enjoy a savory meal and great atmosphere.
author: Nise L.

description: When I am in the city, this is a must place for me all the time. I love eating at Franchino's the food is fresh and hot, the owners are wonderful hosts. I have been going to this restaurant for the past 3 years and no matter what I order, it is DELICIOUS!  The place is cute and cozy.  The only thing that sucks about this is hard to find nearby parking.  If  you want real authentic italian food... this is the place.
author: San S.

description: The pesto gnocchi was good. Risotto was BAD. Tasted like uncooked rice. Pasta was just OK. Nothing really amazing about this place, not sure why it has a 4 star rating.
author: Jessie O.

description:
Seriously best Gnocchi I've ever had in my life!!  Small little place, but they held our reservations for 7 + a baby on a Saturday night  without issue.
Delish!
author: Lisa S.

description: We arrived on a Saturday around 6:30 pm. The place was not full, so we were greeted with a friendly "Buona Sera" from Mr. Franchino himself. This place is awesome. The food is fantastic and you really do feel as if you're in a relative's home, especially since our waitress (Franchino's daughter) told us the daily special by starting with, "Today my mom made..." Anyway, as soon as we arrived the place got completely packed! So be sure to arrive early. The service was a bit slow since there are only about two waiters, the girl I mentioned, and another gentleman named Antonio.
author: Anel E.

description: First, you should know this is a southern Italian restaurant.  Great family owned place....but the food was just ok.  The gnocchi was homemade but NOT handmade.  There's a big difference right there.  I ordered the risotto pescatore and it was just ok.  My partner ordered the gnocchi alla gorgonzola and it was ok but you can get about the same thing at trader joe's in the freezer section.  My mother tried the cappellini alla pomodoro, her favorite, and I felt there was a lack of flavor in general.  I tasted NO garlic, and to me that is just unexcuseable in an Italian restaurant.  The experience was fun, the family owned restaurant has alot of charm, but their food needs a refresher if they are trying to be authentic.  We enjoyed our experience but, as Italians, we were disappointed with the quality of the food.  We will have to try somewhere else next time the parents come to town.
author: jessica b.

description: Love the charm of this family-run establishment. I thought the penne all'amatriciana was good, and the veal was very good. The eggplant parmigiana at the next table over also looked excellent. Super friendly service, felt like a very authentic Italian experience.
author: D K.

description: Cute italian family restaurant, the owners are great, they chat with you and sing a little randomly. The fresh homemade Manicotti was amazing.
author: Lizz G.

description:
I took friends who were visiting from France to Franchino for dinner one evening.  Thought it would be an enjoyable dining experience based on the Yelp reviews.  

The meal was mediocre at best.  My dinner was passable but my friend's meal (pasta in a gloppy white sauce) was barely eaten.  They were decidedly unimpressed and I was embarrassed. 

One could do better at other restaurants in the city.
author: Charles L.

description: They cheerfully accepted a reservation for two at 8:00. Showed up on time, greeted by the owner in his theatrical Italian manner, then watched him seat walk-in couples twice leaving me standing there. I asked why he wasn't seating me and he said, "You only one." I reminded again that we had made reservations, my husband was parking the car and he said, "No matter." I looked around at the cheesy faux Italian decor, walked out and had a great meal up the street. If you like your Italian restaurants Disneyland-style, give it a whirl but don't bother making a reservation.
author: Jo Ann S.

description: This place is a treasure.  Have you heard they make their own pasta and then upon order cut it in front of you?  THEY DO!  Their olive bread and Tuscan bean dip is amazing.  Their cheese is fantastic as is their goat cheese red pepper spread.   Did I mention their homemade cannoli....mmmmm delicious. To top it all of they have great customer service.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Franchino and his wife and daughters serve-up a truly authentic Italian dinning experience. The food focuses on Southern Italian cooking, but they do very well with everything on the menu. Don't waste your time looking around North Beach endlessly. Go in, let Franchino surprise you with some amazing Antipasti and make sure to try any dish that includes Josephine's hand-made pasta. Franchino also has one of the best pallets for Italian wines, but make sure you ask about the price before he opens it, he has some rare wines that he will enthusiastically open if you let him. 
Mangia.
author: Scott S.

description: Southern Italian in North Beach. What could go wrong? An excellent menu and the service was typical for this genre; noisy and flirtatious. The marinara sauce was unspectacular. My salmon sambucco was a bit cold, but very flavorful. Wouldn't go out of my way, but if you are already in the neighborhood, why not?
author: Tony R.

description:
Friday night, about 8:00 PM, we had intended to dine at Tommoso's but the wait was going to be 40 minutes (not unexpected, we'll try them another time).  So we started out on foot up Columbus.  I had heard of the Stinking Rose, we ventured over to check out the menu.  In the process I recalled that Yelper's had posted about a small family owned restaurant a few doors away, so we ventured up the block.  And to our delight we found Franchino!

The owner was out front, and as we were pondering whether to go in, he assured us that "if you don't like, I pay for your meal".  So what did we have to lose, right? By this point, I was sucked in, how could I say "No" to someone so passionate about his business?  As only an Italian gent could do, he reached out and took my hand (I am a gal, by the way) and led us into the restaurant.  As we were being seated, he introduced himself, wife, daughter ... indeed this IS authentically an Italian family business.

I've been reading other reviews this morning, let me get a few things out of the way...

Yes - the restaurant is quite small, roughly 15 tables which themselves are relatively small (by American standards) and close together, and all were full.  But once we got settled, we and everyone dining with us seemed at ease, comfortable and content.

Yes - the owner is a character ... spends most of his time strolling through the restaurant, or out front welcoming customers, blurts out some Italian phrase or lyrics randomly from time to time ... but we found this enchanting, not distracting or annoying.  Really folks, how often do you have the opportunity to even meet the owner of any establishment anymore?  And have the pleasure of supporting a family's livelihood with your patronage?  So what if they are a bit eccentric?  Lighten up, people!

No - this is NOT a good place to bring a party larger than 4 people.  We were a party of 3, and happily we were seated immediately, but at a table in the "middle" of the room which ideally seats 2.  At first we thought "uh oh" (me and two tall men), but again, once we settled in, we were fine.  The 2 diners adjacent to us were asked to scoot over one table so they could get a party of 4 seated together, the "scooters" were not put off by this in the least.  But if you don't like this sort of "folksy" ambiance, don't dine here.

No - don't bother making reservations, if you have a time constraint, allow sufficient time to accommodate a relatively short wait.  The service was prompt and friendly and we have no complaints.  We considered ourselves lucky to get in quickly on a Friday evening, but who knows, we may have "bumped" someone with a reservation.

All this being said, if you are seeking a casual, comfortable and delicious Italian meal, we highly recommend Franchino!

I agree with previous postings, for us greedy Americans, the menu options may be limited (relative to larger establishments), but who cares, as long as what you order is great, right?

Our entrees were absolutely wonderful - all 3 of us raved about our meals.  
I had ravioli in porcini mushroom sauce, it was outrageously good, possibly the best ravioli dish I have ever eaten.  Caesar salad was tasty, ask for light dressing if you are sensitive to this, good but not special.
Hubby had veal Parmesan, tender enough to cut with his fork, I'm not an expert on veal myself, but he proclaimed it "the best" he has ever eaten.
Our guest is visiting from Europe, he ordered gnocchi because a) he loves it, and b) it is one of the most difficult dishes to "do right" and he wanted to give them the ultimate test (in his book).  He was thrilled, found it to be top notch (high praise from one who eats in the real Italy), and when done sopping up the Gorgonzola sauce his plate was almost clean enough to reuse!
Bread was served with the meal, nothing special there by SF bread standards.  But with a bottle of wine and our entrees, we were "fat, dumb and happy" when we waddled back out onto the street.
Prices were reasonable by San Francisco standards, 3 entrees, one side salad, 1 bottle of wine, $100 (not including tip).

Can I say this is the "best Italian food in San Francisco" ?
Well, truthfully no, BUT only because I live in the 'burbs and (until now) have not been one to dine in San Francisco often.  So I'm not qualified to make this claim.
Can I say this is some of the best Italian food I have ever eaten, San Francisco or elsewhere?  ABSOLUTELY!!!!

We were hosting our Dutch guest, our intention was to take him to an authentic San Francisco establishment, show him an "America" he would not find in a strip mall.  
Mission accomplished ... in spades!

Thank you, Franchino Family!  
Can't wait to dine here again!
author: Cheryl M.

description:
Still on my Italian cuisine kick because I'm still on my Italian honeymoon high. I had read about the warm family-run ambiance from fellow yelpers, so I had to go check it out. I met up with my friend Celia last nite, and while I was outside waiting, the owner Franco introduced himself. He's great! It was "not a problem" that I didn't have a reservation. And when I felt bad for standing outside too long, he told me "no problem - it's a Tuesday night." He asked me if I minded that he closed the door since it was a bit chilly, and then stood outside in the cold with me. We conversed. He told me about the specials that his wife had made that evening. And when Celia and I finally got inside, his wife said she would take care of us (I think she takes care of all the patrons). We ordered the cozze marinara (mussels with spicy red wine sauce), Celia ordered the pasta carbonara (with prosciutto, mushrooms, and cream sauce) and I got the gnocchi in Gorgonzola sauce. The food was delicious! We topped off our meal with an order of tiramisu, which confused us for a minute because it was presented to us like a cheesecake - but no worries, it tastes like tiramisu. It was creatively presented. The grand finale? As we were about to leave, Franco shushes the entire restaurant because the lady at the table came all the way from PA to hear him sing. Of course we couldn't leave (I can imagine him running after us and scolding us for walking out on him). He had a "headache," so he said he would only sing a little. It was a great performance, and before he could end the song, his mother jumped in with the final lines. He looked "upset" that she stole his thunder. 

A great family run restaurant, for a great home cooked Italian meal. Definitely a place to come back to!
author: Annie Y.

description: After looking for a good Italian restaurant in the city, and reading great reviews on here, my fiance and I had to try Franchino. We got there (horrible trying to find a parking spot like the rest of SF!) and the owner was outside talking to people passing by...He brought us in and sat us down and introduced his wife and daughter. They served us throughout the night. It is very small inside...But some homey! I ordered my favorite dish-Chicken piccata and my fiance got the gnocchi. Yum! I loved the sauce on my chicken and I thought his gnocchi were amazing! I thought the price was pretty good too...I usually bring home some food when I eat out and didn't have anything to bring...But that's okay I guess! If I lived in the city, I'd go here more often! Try it!!!
author: Katy B.

description:
Visiting SF and went to this restaurant on a friend's recommendation. Fabulous! From the outside it is a kitschy little hole-in the wall. Step inside and the friendly welcome, cozy seating, and outstanding food completely win you over. 

The marinated calamari was nicely presented and delicious. Rissotto - fabulous.
